description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/hk30izlfEGe

A spring-mounted ball-isolator designed to fit onto the legs of the Printrbot Jr and reduce the vibrations transferred to the table/floor/shelf etc it is sitting on (and thus the noise produced by the printer) .

Based on the design by lazzymonk, I adapted the "base" cup and the spring base into one piece (i.e. no glue required) and adapted the "top" cup to fit onto the legs of the Printrbot Jr. There are two types of "cup" in the download - three "normal" ones which fit onto three of the legs of the Printrbot Jr and one "different" one which has an extra slot to house a nearby protruding screw which holds down the electronics inside the body. I modelled this in Inventor to make it easier to tweak the parameters between edits (sorry freeware tweakers!). This version should be just right - a nice, snug fit around the Printrbot Jr feet and a strong (but not stiff) spring action in the base. Each cup is 3mm deep (so you should use ball bearing > 6mm diameter) and 25mm wide. I opted for an 8mm ball bearing as I was able to buy grade 10 (low grade number = really smooth) ball bearings relatively cheaply from Simply Bearings (UK: http://simplybearings.co.uk/shop/index.html). Smaller diameter balls will bring the two cups closer together (more chance of them clashing or sticking together) and larger diameters will not give the ball much room to move around within the cup (reducing the damping and risking the ball rolling out of the cup). You could use a marble or even print a ball bearing (definitely needs hi-res!). At a push, you can fit 4x bases and caps on a Printrbot Jr stock printbed. I used a smaller skirt (2mm from the model as opposed to my normal 5mm) which helped.

I installed some new sliding pocket doors in the house and I did not like the little plastic guide block hardware it came with....these guide blocks fit at the bottom and make sure the door does not swing and hit the walls.  The last picture above shows the standard blocks that come with the door; they are ugly, and protrude out into the door way area.  
I decided it I would just make up my own that fits nice and flush.  It is specific to the width of the opening, but can be scaled up/down to adjust any opening I suppose. I printed it in natural white ABS and it works/looks great.  Much better than the original part.

description.text: A working 3D printed friction shifter! See video at http://youtu.be/fLMA-8aSsDM While friction shifters don't "click" into gear like index shifters - they have advantages. A friction shifter is much more tolerant of minor problems like slightly bent derailers or worn cables / housings. Heavily tested with 7-speed setup - but should work with any number of speeds (front or rear derailer). I just biked from Seattle to Portland using this shifter (204 miles) without any problems. With 300+ miles on same shifter - I'm reasonably confident it's pretty solid and should last a while.

The shifter has three parts bottom_assembly, lever and washer. I've included Solidworks designs files and IGES format - if you're printing just get the 3 STL files. Printed on Makerbot Replicator 2:
Black PLA
2 Shells 100% Infill
About 1.5 hour print time The above settings are fairly conservative / fairly bomb-proof. You can probably get an adequately tough print using less infill (but you may want to add another shell or two). If you want a fully solid print with Makerware 2.2 or later - create a custom profile and set the infill style as linear. I found this was creating some cosmetic print issues - so I've gone back to the default hexagonal fill (which seems strong enough). Non-printed parts:
2x #10 Nylon Lock Nuts
2x #10 x 1" Machine Screws
3x #8 Washers (yup - they fit)
Splicing tape (or thin piece of rubber) for mounting (standard electrical tape does not work) Assembly / install should be pretty intuitive. The three washers are all stacked on top of the lever - and primarily act as a spacer so the 1" machine screws fit. The screw works as a friction adjustment and allows for a large amount of wear before anything needs to be replaced. Use the splicing tape (decent hardware stores will have this) to assure a snug mount that doesn't shift around. You might be able to substitute rubber bands / something else for this. --Do not over-tighten the handlebar mounting bolt - that's one way to crack the base.-- Make sure the screw fits in the lever without binding (it's OK if it binds a bit in the base piece). If it binds - drill it out until it doesn't (otherwise the shifter may loosen/tighten itself). Adding a small amount of bike lube between the washers may also help prevent things from loosening (do not lube anyplace else). Want to adjust your shifter using your metric bike Allen wrenches? Just use a standard #10-32 cap screw. It uses a 5/32" hex wrench to drive - which is virtually identical to a 4mm hex wrench (this is how I currently have things setup). You can also use a #10-32 thumb screw for tool-free adjusting. Expect a few friction adjustments in the first mile or
two - then again around mile 50 - and less frequently after that. I just biked from Seattle to Portland (204 miles) with no adjustments! Over 400+ miles on the same print so far! Minor 1.1 Update:
The screw holes are a bit wider and shouldn't need to be drilled out to avoid binding now. Removed the top "stop" (the derailer's stop takes care of this) and repositioned the bottom stop for easier reach.

comments.text: You'd likely have to have a spring mechanism to accomplish that ability, or incorporate the orientation of the reel and use gravity. Upside down = an internal pin slides out of the way of the crank and allows the gear holding the fishing line to spin freely. Right side up = internal pin slides back into position restricting freely spinning gear to only spinning in one direction.

This is a charging stand for the Arizer Solo Vaporizer. It uses the supplied Arizer wall-wart power supply as-is. The stand is rather primitive -- it was one of my first OpenSCAD designs -- but it works well. I've been using mine for a little over a year. The Arizer Solo Vaporizer is a marvelous gadget. There are a couple of drawbacks to its design, however. The first: While it can be used while charging, because the charging port is on the bottom, you can't stand it upright while charging. The second: The charging plug is a straight plug instead of a right angle plug -- so I had to design the stand a little taller that I would have liked in order to accommodate the straight plug. While installing the charging plug into the stand is fairly straightforward, I've included some pics to illustrate the preferred method of getting the plug in there. Get the plug in first, then work the cord into the "keepers." After the charging plug is installed into the stand, the plug barrel should be vertical. But the plug will, at first, lean a bit forward in the stand instead of being vertical. As the plug's molded-in strain relief gets used to being bent, the plug will stay vertical -- you can help it along by bending the strain relief a bit before you insert it -- see the cutaway pics to help illustrate what I mean. You can also make the plug more vertical by pushing the cord into the stand a little bit more. The stand is designed to have the tip of the plug rising just above the sides of the stand so it is the first thing that touches the bottom of the Solo when you're inserting it into the stand. It's very important to insert the Solo into the stand gently - without forcing. Get the plug started into the bottom of the Solo before fully inserting the Solo into the stand. I printed this with 20% infill. You may want a higher percentage to provide more "heft", but even at 100%, when it's empty, it's going to slide around at the mercy of the very stiff charging cord. When the Solo in in the stand, that's not a problem. I put a sticky-foam sheet on the bottom (not seen in the pics) to help protect any furniture it's placed upon. Rubber stick-on feet might be a good idea, too.

comments.text: The Solo's shape is not as complicated as it may first appear.  It's just a cylinder with the four corners shaved off.  I've just uploaded the OpenSCAD source for your perusal.  It's not intended to be used with the customizer, but you can download it and dig out the dimensions, build it in OpenSCAD, etc. It was amazingly easy to do the original "just-a-stand" version: a truncated cone with the solo's shape cut out.   Adding the power plug and cord path, on the other hand, really taxed my minor OpenSCAD skills, but it was interesting to try various ideas to achieve it.  I'd do it a little differently, code-wise, today.  And while the design still works, I'd shave down the outside of the cone using a donut shape as the cutter.  It would give the plain cone-shape a more pleasing concave outline and cut down on plastic, too.

The last nickel calibration test I designed gave no real feedback on how to fix the problem. This one should allow for measurements and corrections.
This one is exactly 21.21 mm wide in both the x and y. The slots are the same lengths (21.21mm) but a little wide (3mm)to disregard the width of the slot until the x and y are perfect.
Please like and upload photos of your made thing! I love to see this still working for everyone so many years later!

Disclaimer!
"This is based on my limited knowledge of using, building a 3D printer (Prusa Mendel) and all the things I've learned up to this point (I started in March of 2011). It has been pointed out to me that this may not be the end-all-be-all of calibration tests. This test assumes that you have a working knowledge of calibrating your firmware steps per mm and are comfortable doing so. It also assumes that your extruder has been precisely calibrated. Please use at your own discretion. It works for me." Step 1- Print using zero extra shells, no scaling, or widen. Step 2- Attempt to place a nickel in the circle once the print is done. If it does not sit perfectly in the circle with no extra space on the sides then move to step 3. Step 3- Mark the two slots as needed to remember which is X and Y. Step 4- Remove piece from bed. Step 5- Measure the insides of each slot. Also, attempt to slide the nickel through. If the coin can not pass you will be increasing the steps per mm for that axis. Vice versa if coin easily passes through with space to spare. Step 6- You should have two numbers from measuring the slots. I had 23 on x and 22 on Y. Step 7- Divide your number by the width of the nickel (21.21mm) For me it was 21.21/23x= 0.9221739130434783 and 21.21/22y=0.9640909090909091 Step 8- Multiply this long number by your current steps per mm in the firmware. Mine was 42.42. So, 0.9221739130434783x*42.42=39.11861739130435 This number will become your NEW steps per mm for that axis. Repeat this step for Y. Step 9- Upload this to your board and print again. Repeat until the coin barely fits through the slot and fits snugly in to the hole. Step 10- To calibrate Z, simply use digital calipers to measure the height of the test piece and use the same method to change the steps per mm.

comments.text: Do not calibrate on something as small as a nickel. At such a small scale, any errors in measurement are multiplied. Scale with larger prints.

comments.text: Please explain that to me. I was under the impression that since I've ordered the nozzle head to move 21.21mm inside length of the box and it moves more or less how would tightening my belt or changing my pulleys help? They are already very tight with barely any slack.
comments.author: merlinjim

comments.text: Lets say the belt has some slack in it. When the motor driving the belt turns it first has to take up the slack in the belt before the build platform ever begins to move. Since the gcode is based on motor position, this slack (also known as lash) is subtracted from the total movement of the plate. This makes the true measured movement relative to the build platform less then what the printer thinks it is moving. I hope this makes sence.
comments.author: MrJohn

comments.text: These are not as fixed as you may think.
comments.author: merlinjim

comments.text: Does this assume you have your flow and feed rates ok? If your flow rates are too low, will you be making your number of steps smaller than what they really are? For what I am thinking, the inner circles/shapes will be a compensated until they fit the nickel, but then the outside perimeter measurement will be too small.

description.text:
This is the third lot 20 tiles that I created to make Tudor Buildings for my Tudor village that is 00 scale ( 4mm to the foot, 1:76.2) model railways. Can be also used for HO scale, British themed but could be used elsewhere. Please note tiles TT-551, TT-552 and TT-553 are currently missing, will add them when I draw them up did note need them yet!! The cover photo is of more buildings that are made using these tiles, as mentioned in other things I will upload all the printed parts to make these buildings, plus I will put together some pictures to make some other buildings I have already built. But it is best to use your own imagination to come up with your own designs. The Cover photo is another of 14 models that I made up as a small diorama that I gave to my family and friends for Xmas 2014, So they fantastic display items not just for model railways or wargamming. So even the rest of the family would be impressed by these models There are about 100 tiles in the set so far I will upload in lots of 20 tiles.
I have divided plastic containers that contain my tiles and I just pick them out and glue them together in the design I want, It's a bit like Lego. If you have any questions about anything I have uploaded please ask questions.
If you have a request for something I shall see what I can do, no promises though on that one. Don't forget to check my other things relating to model making.

Ordbot Hardron and modified Flashforge

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Doesn't Matter

0.1mm to 0.2mm

Notes: With the Tudor tiles the largest nozzle i would recommend is a 0.4 I personally use a 0.2mm nozzle for my printing of these Tudor Tiles but have printed them with a 0.4 nozzle on my other printer.

PAINTING I paint the black and the white on the Tudor buildings with Humbrol 33 Matt Black and 34 Matt White. I find the Enamel paints have a better Matt finish compared to the Acrylics which seem to have a sheen about them.

title: 10mm LED Holder with Diffuser and Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This LED holder includes a diffuser cover, plug for holding the LED in-place, and a clamp with stick for sticking the thing into other things. More information and pictures can be found here: http://wp.me/p2hTaI-1N The stick was made to fit our needs, but the whole connection is made in such a way you could design your own piece with a part to fit inside the clamp. This could make the perfect bicycle head/tail light with the right attachment, or maybe a small tripod could turn it into a bookcase light... I'll clean up the Blender file and post soon.

Print all pieces. The only one that needs raft and support is the base, as it is conical up to a flat back plane area (mega-overhang). I printed with 10% infill and I thought the sides of the cone were going to shake my ToM apart; be prepared!
The diffuser cover has built-in supports which can be cut off with a utility knife (be careful not to cut the actual clip off!). Also, you can print the diffuser with natural ABS for a warm "lightbox" effect (as in my pictures), or PLA for a translucent lens effect. Certainly you could stick gels behind either for colored lights, or maybe use markers on PLA. You could also use any color LED you want (I used an ultra-bright cool white LED).
The base item needs to be finished like so: paint the inside and outside with black acrylic paint and silver-leaf the inside cone after the paint is dry. NOTE: try not to paint inside the cylinder where the LED slides into, as that may make it too tight a fit. Paint the back and edges of the plug black, but try not to paint the arms (again, too tight).
The clamp is sized for a #6 bolt and wing nut, but I haven't actually put on in it; it may need to be adjusted for your bolt.
Finally, the arms on the back plug may need to be sanded down to fit flush with the back of the base after the LED is in-place. However, there should be enough room inside for a resistor and maybe heat-shrink tubing before running the wires through the hole in the plug, depending upon your soldering skills (mine suck).
Hot glue or superglue all the pieces together if desired, plug in the LED and enjoy!

title: e3d v6 bracket for Mendel Max 2

description.text:
This e3d V6 bracket has seen 10+ iterations in an attempt to get the perfect dimensions and allow for a perfect filament path. If you have the right speeds then flexible filament should work great with this bracket. Run the PTFE tube as far up as possible. You'll need: 2 - M3 screws
2 - M3 Nyloc nuts Insert the nyloc nuts into the prints, mount e3d, tighten fastener into bracket and around e3d. Mount the whole thing to the carriage of the MM2. If you have a heated chamber or are printing high temp materials like ABS or PC-ABS then I recommend printing this in at least ABS or something with a even higher glass transition temperature. Good luck, feedback appreciated! Released through my company http://northernlayers.com

author: NorthernLayers

title: Robo3d R1 E3D Flex Filament Guide

description.text:
April 14, 2017 Update: Apparently, the R1+ has a different feeder geometry, so it does not fit the R1+. R1 is still all good though :-).
June 21, 2016 Update: A few users have had problems and we're trying to figure out if its the dimensional accuracy of the printed part or if its something less fundamental. I'm going to get back to printing with flex and i'm sure the part will be updated.
Nov 22, 2015 Update: A user has successfully used this part using PETG with the stock hexagon hot end. They couldn't print with PETG previously without the material bunching up under the hot end. Keep the posts coming!
Nov 15, 2015 Update: By popular demand (2 requests in comments), I've added a variant where the PTFE flare is removed. Anyone with a robo3D should be able to use this, but I need the community to test it. I would first try it with regular filament, to make sure the hobbed bolt and bearing still push the filament as efficiently, and then try with Flex. Try slow speeds at first (10mm/sec?). Thanks! Video Here: https://youtu.be/5TzSODHT6Zk 215 Degrees, 15mm/sec, Filaflex, 110% extrusion, 0.1mm layer height, 0.3mm nozzle. I have a Robo3d R1 with an E3D Hot end and I've found that flex material (NinjaFlex, FilaFlex) does not print reliably, if at all. When installing the E3D hot end, it is suggested to drill out the 'filament hole' beneath the hobbed bolt so the PTFE tube can be cut just under the bolt. While this worked OK, I had reliability issues. The problem is that printing with Flex is like pushing a rope: it simply buckles in the transverse direction rather than applying force axially. If the rope is constrained in a tube, then as long as the axial force is higher than the friction of the ''rope' against the tube, it will slide through it. I made a part that fills in the gaps between the hobbed bolt, bearing, and 'tube' so when the flex filament is pushed, it can't box-car and buckle. This part is the result of many iterations and now I'm finally at a design that is reliable. Instructions:
1) Get a Robo3D, install the E3D hot end, and drill out the filament hole. This will allow the PTFE tube to extend from the hobbed bolt all the way down to the hot end.
2) Print this part with its large flat face down on the bed.
3) Install: cut back the PTFE tube so it sits in the small half-moon feature when this part is installed.
4) Enjoy printing with flex. I Print with Filaflex : 215 degrees, 20mm/sec, 110% extrustion.
These settings are fine with Ninjaflex as well. I've found that this part can be left in the extruder assembly and material can be changed out as usual: compressing the springs, yanking the old material out, inserting the new material and turning the gear. If there is interest, I can modify this part to be used with a non-E3D hot end, but someone else will need to test it. I'd just make a channel where the PTFE tube is, which wil guide the filament into the stock filament hole under the bolt.

No

Yes

0.05mm (50 microns works best)

100%
Support material has to be removed form area where PTFE tube pops through.

comments.text: This is generally a symptom of what we're trying to fix: poor feeding of flexible material.  To troubleshoot: if the material is not bunching up under the bolt, but it is sputtering, the bolt is not biting into the material and feeding it at the same rate that it is rotating.  Either the distance between the hobbed bolt and the adjacent bearing is too great, or there is material stuck in the grooves in the bolt (flex is slipping), or the printed part is causing too much friction with the adjacent bearing, causing the flex to catch on it and not feed.  Let me know if this helps.

Some doors designed for Zombicide Black Plague but will work with other games like flashpoint.
Medieval design along with a more modern version.
Door openings are around 36 high x 20mm wide. Base is 28mm square. About 40mm tall overall.
Plates and individual pieces are available.
Each plate is an entire door. Z1 - Arched block frame door
Z2 - Rectangular wooden door
Z3 - Arched column door (single opening door)
Z4 - Modern rectangular door
Z5 - Improved arched column door with 2 opening doors (more pieces)
Z6 - Prison/Barred door
Z7 - Modern reinforced door
Z8 - Modern wooden door
Z9 - Modern door
Z10 - Modern steel door They use a universal base (except Z5).
"Door Base - Dual Hinge" will allow the door to be hung left or right.
"Door Base - Left Pivot (mirrored)" will allow the door to be hung on the other side of the frame without the extra hole the dual hinge base has.
Z2, Z4, Z6, Z7, Z8, Z9 and Z10 use the same frame.
Z4 and Z7 doors are identical front and back.
Z6 is a single piece door. 19.10.2017 Z6-10 added. Z3/5 base modified

06.03.2017 Z6 door added, parts renamed

This thing was created so my AML cars would couple to my AristoCraft cars and locomotives.
The couplers are made in the closed position so the cars will not come uncoupled even with a long train. The mounting screw to be tightened because the coupler pivots on the bolt pin. This method gives the coupler the most movement with strength and there is no worries of the mounting screw loosing.

title: Sturdy Foot For 2020 Extrusion - Folgertech 2020 - K8200 - 3Drag

description.text:
I'm building a new printer using 2020 extrusion. I needed a set of legs that not only looked good but also added strength to the frame. Plus they had to be adjustable.
The adjustable foot has a 1/4-20 X 1" hex bolt (an M6 would probably fit) that has been permanently held in place by melting the edges with a soldering iron so it would not fall out. There is also a 1" diameter anti-skid pad that I got from Home Depot to keep if from sliding around.

comments.text: I haven't used the Line Sensors/Ping Mount in any classes yet but have used a modified version of the base robot in a couple of classes I've taught in our makerspace. My version of the robot uses a custom Arduino shield with the stepper drivers, 5V Buck Boost converter for power, serial eeprom and room for a serial ram chip. I modified TinyBasicPlus to add commands to run the robot and draw text using Hershey vector fonts stored in half of the eepprom. The other half of the eeprom is used as a disk drive to store TinyBasicPlus programs. I use a cheap bluetooth LE shield so the robot can be programmed or operated from an iPhone or Android device. It can also be programmed over the USB serial connection as well.

title: Cat food top with spoon slot & whiskers

description.text:
Not just a cat food can top. It's got whiskers. And even better - it's got a slot for the spoon. I got tired of cleaning up a spoon every time I serve up the cats' food. Just stick it back in there and put the top back on. It doesn't get better than that. 75mm diameter. A little x-y scaling will get you on to different sizes cans. I printed this using semi flex, because I just got my first reel of it and wanted to try it out. PLA would be find, too, but the semiflex worked out really well.
Of course you will want to rotate it 180 degrees to print it.
P.S. Also might be good for those of us who eat icing out of the can and want to have the spoon ready to go!

author: Evilman

description.text:
Hi, since i had rough time with most of fan designs i tried so far so i created these.
Stand part has upper holes that fit on my hot end but i already implemented couple using only copper wire and that works well too. Point was to have cleaner, quieter hot end while reducing dust and particles building up on most designs i used. Ease of access and ability to change fan by taking whole assembly off was must because these things die and get noisy at most peculiar of times, like when on some demo or show, so unplugging assembly because of noisy fan became feat of design. Also angled wings on both sides keep intake and output away from hot end and onto platform and passive cooler on most kits. This is my first part i share with you good folks at thingiverse after some time stalking you all, so be gentle ;)

Printer:

meta.frame.XL

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 - 0.5

Infill:

80 - 100

Notes: printed both 0.3 and 0.5 layer height at some 80% infill or more to keep breeze at bay.
Printed bunch with both ABS and PLA and all work well when used on print heads for both PLA and ABS printing. Meaning if you print on ABS temperatures and this fan is printed in PLA it still wont melt because of separation and connection point on the top.

For optimum noise reduction and flow all four fan screws must be griped.
If used with hot end without holes to attach this you can use copper wire
with shrouds only and screws
Stand must be facing angled up opposite hot end and both shrouds should blow upwards. Almost forgot, make sure to think wiring trough before bolting them shut, two installs
so far both times had to repeat steps 1-5 :p

comments.text: So i switched the supplier of filament for cheaper one and this new filament is causing lots of problems, it is getting bent inside hot end on even lowest of temperatures. I solved this by removing shrouds from my vent, only leaving stand on. This was first filament that required this but clearly shrouds do well for preventing underlying winds but also hot end gets bit to hot for lower priced filaments.

description.text:
Recently I was digitizing some old 16mm movies.  Some of them date back to 1959 and have splices that are failing.  I needed to make new splices that would feed through my $25 craigslist projector -- where are you going to get a 16mm film editing system today, without paying a fortune?  Right!  I made my own.  Overlap both ends on this guide (press down onto teeth to ensure alignment) and slice with a razor blade.  Then use "Hollywood Approved" tape (read "generic office tape") to join the ends, making sure not to cover any sprocket holes.  So far, so good.
BTW, I printed mine in glow-in-the-dark PLA.  That's just what I had in the printer -- but aren't you jealous?   :-)

You can print your own Anchorman.   I have included files for both editing and printing the anchorman; along with an easy to follow instructions.   The idea is was to make a movable multimedia art piece.      The design has a head (head mostly empty), jaw, and an optional stand.      
I am looking forward to what other people will do with the design; think about it.   You can add; brains, gears, motors, lights, or anything that your imagination can envision.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

20

Notes: Anchorman was printed on a Printerbot Play (which is my first printer) and this is my first attempt at a custom design. The object can be printed with body and jaw separately (which I would highly recommend) or in one part if you are up for a challenge, with no reward. The Anchorman will not have either lockjaw or stage fright. The stand can be printed at 100% scale for loose fit; or 99+% scale for tight fit. You have the source file and can edit and modify.. I am looking forward to punk rock anchormen etc. It would be great to have a larger print of this object. The play prints nice quality (see the intricate vase in the background). but has a very limited print bed size.

New to 3d Printing and Cad I am new to 3d printing and it is great fun! I decided to make my own design and after watching TV I was inspired to draw and then print a replacement "anchorman." The anchorman will say anything you want as long as you pull his strings.
Made this remix for newer users of 3d printing.

title: GI Joe Toss n Cross (Bridge layer)

description.text:
Another GI Joe model for my game, drawn using my old toy and calipers. Although the file is presented full scale, I modeled it so that it was optimized when printed at 25%. Unless you stay in that range it may have too much or too little detail.
The bridge layer tank.  A fun toy, essential equipment when my vehicles needed to get from the couch to the coffee table!  
The bridge doesn't unfold like the toy did, sorry.  My original (articulating) test pieces kept breaking so I went with a manual "lay out the bridge yourself" process instead.  I printed the bridge piece out twice, glued them together in the folded position.  Then I made another pair of bridge pieces and glued them together in the unfolded position.  When the folded bridge is set on top of the tank it holds in place and won't fall off when you are pushing it around the table.  
Everything can be printed without supports.  The chassis is printed treads down, as it would sit in real life.  The bridge piece is also printed right side up, you need two.  Finally, the guns (you need two of them also) are printed with the barrel horizontal.  The guns should be glued to the chassis - there's a raised pad for each to sit on.
Update 3/5/16  Added a second version of the bridge section [Called 'bridge filled in'].  This one doesn't have the thin center portion as seen on the toy,due to some users having trouble with thin features.  You do not need this file unless you have trouble with the original.
Much respect and gratitude to the men and women of our Armed Forces (past and present).  Your sacrifice allows people like me to live in peace and freedom.  /You/ are the real American heroes.

This file is a free download.  Please note that it is listed as “non-commercial”.  Neither you nor I are allowed to buy or sell physical copies of this 3D model.   You are allowed (and encouraged) to print copies for your own personal use. The GI Joe motorcycle with a machine gun sidecar.  I especially like the 1980s skinny tires.  If this was made in 2015 they'd have to be at least twice as wide or you would get laughed at.

Since it is small it should not take take too long and is probably easier than gluing a lot of pieces together - as I learned on my previous FANG Cobra helicopter design.  Also, I printed these in fine detail setting since they are so small, though you can do what you wish.

If you're not quite sure you are getting circles instead of ovals, try out my new, patent-worthy-but-idontmeanthat invention: the roundness detector! Made to fit a fender washer so you have something round to compare it to. Auto-aligning, too. Isn't that special?
If you download now, we'll throw in the "quicklash" calibration test. Get it ballparked in with the Round-ness Detector and then fine tune with quicklash.

Print it. Drop a fender washer in the well. Take a picture directly above it. THEN remove the print from the print bed, very carefully. If you wait to put the fender in, you might not get a chance. The thin walls are a bonus calibration feature, but they are kinda hard to keep when you pry it up.
Use quicklash after you've eliminated as much mechanical backlash as possible. Iterate prints of the quicklash (designed to be skeined and printed quickly) with incremental changes to the X and Y values in the Lash module of Skeinforge, and lay them out in a matrix. By eye you will be able to pick the best one.

description.text:
More playing with wrecks :). I started with Da5id's excellent Rhino clone and added the hatch from OutOfStep's Ground Plunderer. Then I modeled the interior of the Rhino (OpenSCAD and Inkscape again), removed all the doors, etc. Then I based it (Blender), placing some of the hatches around and adding some damage, then dropped the pack off Garin's Space Marine in the dirt for good measure. I'm honestly not sure how to best print this thing; open to suggestions. I'm going to try Meshmixer and see if it's supports look more promising than the Simplify3D defaults. I'll upload a supported model if I come up with one, or else I'll just rip some more overhanging parts off with more damage! 12/5/2015 Update:
  • I've uploaded a new (unsupported) version. The prior (v9) version had a void underneath the rear hatch that was fine in terms of printing but totally unnecessary. This one removes that void and also cleans up the bottom surface.
    • 12/3/2015 Update:
  • The supported model still has some issues in terms of holes, but the unsupported model appears clean. I actually printed the supported version and just green stuff'd a couple of tiny spots, but you might want to instead start with the unsupported model and go from there.
    • 10/12/2015 Update:
  • There are a few small holes through the model that don't preclude printing but need a little work; I'll re-upload when I have a chance to work on them. If you're excited and want to print, though, go for it -- they really aren't a big deal.
  • I've uploaded a version of the model with supports generated with Meshmixer. I've printed this! Not totally clean, but looks pretty good. I'll get some pictures of that up once I've cleaned it up a little more.

title: Robins Birdhouse - The Real Deal for a Robins Home

description.text:
OK, here's my entry for the Birdhouse Competition.  Please feel free to download it and print one (or many!)  
As always, I've really tried to keep it simple - partly because I'm new to 3D printing and the learning curve is steep! I can't possibly compete with some of the fantastic technical designs here, but instead I've opted to followed the advice of the 'Bird Wildlife Organisations' on recommended sizes and preferred openings for Robins - so hopefully this Birdhouse will actually be liked and lived in by real Robins :-)  
It's a 'one shot print' in Low (faster) print mode, but it really does print nicely (see gallery). Despite it's size, it's firm and strong when printed but only uses 188 grams of PLA.  
Measurements are 140mm wide, 230mm heigh (inc. mounting lips) and 150mm deep.  
It's designed to fix onto a flat wall, the hollow back was decided upon for two reasons, to save on PLA and easy removal of the model from the build platform. If you wish to attach it to a different surface (a tree for example), there is an inner lip that will accommodate the insertion of a push-fit back (made of anything you like really!). It needs to measure 136mm wide x 180mm heigh and push fits from the inside. I have included a 136mm x 20mm 'slat' in the files so that you can 3D print a back if you prefer (you will need x9 of these slats to cover the whole back).  
This 'slat' can also be used to form a front vertical shield plate (x1 or x2 slats can be used - see Gallery photo). Some Bird Wildlife Organisations thing this shield is preferred by Robins, but others disagree and say the fully open front is best?)   
Ideally, should be wall mounted between 6 and 15 feet from the ground and away from any predator access (ie. cats etc.), meaning mounted away from any high fence posts, shed roofs and easily climbable trees!  
Enjoy - hope you adopt some feathered friends as a result of downloading and printing this Robins Birdhouse :-)

This Birdhouse prints from a single file. It is designed to print with the back (where the mounting holes are) flat on the build platform. You may have to turn the model using the build software to best fit your printers build plate. Sat on the build plate after printing, the measurements are: 140mm deep, 230mm long (inc. mounting lips) and 150mm heigh (see gallery photo) I built this on my Makerbot Replicator 2 (Firmware Version 7.2) with the following settings:
Applies to both Birdhouse and optional 'Slat(s)' Exported the print file from MakerWare to SD Card and built directly using the printer SD Card slot
Blue tape on build plate
1.75mm PLA Filament (in my case - black)
Design Software: Autodesk 123D Design - Version 1.2.42
Build Software: MakerWare Version 2.2.1.58
Resolution: Low (faster)
Infill: 10%
Shells: 2
Layer Height: 0.30mm
Temp: 230c
Speed while Extruding: 90mm/s
Speed while Travelling: 150mm/s
Build time: Well, birds take days to build a nest - this Birdhouse took much, much less time that that ;-) Any questions - please just ask . . . . . .

comments.text: I have some super cute birds (not robins---sparrows maybe?) that roost on the pencil-thin ledge above my apartment door, so I'm going to print this and secure it up there so that they don't have to squeeze together anymore and have a little room. Plus the sides will be perfect for blocking the wind! This is perfect for just the use I need :) Will post pics after printing!

My girlfriend was looking for something like a light table that she could put a light behind and trace through paper with, so I decided to take this 11"x13" piece of glass that we had picked up at the hardware store for $8 (Ace hardware, but all the hardware stores will sell glass to-cut), and print some legs so that it works like an easel.  I'm more satisfied and picturing more uses for it than I intended.  You could use it to just comfortably read a book, hold a laptop, or hold paper for drawing.  With glass or acrylic, it's easy to backlight for use with sketching/tracing.
My glass was 3mm thick, so I designed the model to print as if it were 2.8mm thick, so that it would be a nice press-fit.  I'm really surprised about how well it holds onto the glass.  I nudged it on with a hammer, and now it holds really snug.  I've included the cad file so you can adjust the thickness if you need, for different types of materials.  The legs curled up a bit while printing, but they still fit on the glass snug enough that it's sturdy.
Also, the plastic is super slick on the table, so I glued some rubber sheet to the bottom of the feet so it wouldn't slide.
Addition:  I added a STEP cad file so that you can adjust the width of the slot for the material that you're using.  The width of the slot on the uploaded STLs is 2.8mm, a perfect snug fit for 3mm glass.  If you're working with a different material, you can adjust the width.  If a different cad format would be better, let me know and I can upload.  If you're struggling to adjust the width, send me a message or leave a comment and I can upload STLs for the desired width.  The way Onshape is set up, it would literally take a minute to go back and change the number and download the new STL.  Also, if you're using Onshape (free account up to 5GB storage), I have it saved as a public file, so if you search "Glass Plate Easel Holder," you should be able to find it.

title: 2016 Happy New Year Fun Glasses
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I went googling for images of New Year’s Glasses looking for ideas to make some 2016 New Year glasses for this year. I found several ideas (which I posted in the pictures) and also found a model here that apparently also got its inspiration from some of the same older year glasses available commercially. I tried printing it to see how it worked but I had several issues like the hinges were fused and didn’t work and they also broke easily. The glasses were also too small as if sized for children and uncomfortable on the nose’s skin due to the sharp edges of the numbers.
I ended up starting from scratch and making a new set that should work when printed even with less than perfect materials and settings. I made the hinges rugged and the glasses easy on the nose’s skin as well as on the ears. I also included two versions of the arms the standard length (most common) and longer ones. Thanks for the inspiration from previous ideas and enjoy this New Year’s Eve. If you want to paint the numbers in different colors print the glasses in white material to have a good color base. I printed the arms with black PLA at 220 degrees and 45 degrees bed.
The Glasses themselves I printed them with white PETG at 345 degrees and 100 degrees bed.
Fill is 10% and no need for supports because they are already in the uploaded STL file. Don't forget to cut them off before inserting the arms.
You will also need to use some CA or gorilla glue to secure the arms in place. Enjoy. auggie.

Sketchup Make All parts designed sketchup make.

Here's the recipe for how I designed this thing: Start with two concentric spheres, one larger than the other. Use a big "move" brush to push parts of the outer sphere into the inner sphere, revealing the surface of the inner sphere. Continue nudging the outer sphere until an interesting network of surfaces or a vine is showing. Subtract the inner sphere from the outer sphere leaving just the vine. Remesh or retopologize as necessary to clean up the mesh. Finally add a smaller sphere inside the remaining vine. If the sphere doesn't touch the vine, then it will freely move once it's printed. A blast of compressed air (like Dust-Off) will get the sphere spinning pretty fast! It also can glide on a smooth surface like a desk or table.  
Update: I have uploaded the vine and ball as separate files in case someone wants to try printing each in a different color. I don't have a way to test this so if it works, please upload a photo. If you want to print in one color, do not use these separate files.

I used ReplicatorG to prepare the file, a MakerBot Replicator2 with the Replicator 2 slicing defaults and the following settings with white MakerBot PLA to do the printing: Infill = 10%
Layer Height = 0.200
Shells = 1
Feedrate = 40
Travel Feed = 55
Temperature = 220 I used a raft with full support. Be patient removing the support structure as the clearance between the sphere and vine is pretty tight.

title: Hot end fan mount Geeetech Rostock mini G2

description.text: I noticed my Geeetech Rostock mini G2 could not do a PLA print without a fan to help cool down freshly printed PLA. I looked around for a fan duct I liked and found one by "Jian" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:451667). However could not find a mount to install it to my Rostock printer so I created my own. To fit the mount to the printer you'll need 2 screws, 1x m3 x ~12mm, 1x m4 x ~25mm and a m4 nut. You should have these screws as extra's from the Rostock build kit. To attach the fan duct you will need 2 additional m3 x 8mm or 10mm screws also from the build kit

Printer:

Geeetech Rostock mini G2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes: I used 1.2mm perimeter for strength of the part.

Svitovit – solar the two-fold sign with a deep sacral essence, expressed in the symbolic Union of two arhitekti symbols – Grabovica and Kladnica. Svitovit double swastika is actually a symbol designed to unite and to interpret itself in the symbolism of their etymological predecessors.
Our ancestors believed that in Svitavice concluded the Union of two fundamental principles – the Celestial Fire and the Earthly Waters. If Gromovik is a powerful military talisman, the Chanter is a sign of eternal rebirth and revival, allegory of the victory of the gods of light over the dark. The combination of these characters is the unique complex sign, expressing the harmony of the universe contained within an infinite chain of transformations. Svitovit, thus, find yourself with the dynamics of propranlol world order.
The connection of Heaven and Earth, enclosed in this symbol is understood as the creative the creative impulse that brings the real world in new clean soul. In this regard, and provided that the total solar energy Svetovit is a protective symbol that drives the generation of Navi.

comments.text: So im going to begin printing this massive beauty tomorrow (very nice model btw). The thing i was wondering about is what do i use to connect them together?
comments.author: Matssol

comments.text: If u look in the files you will see that there is 14x26_2.stl and 14x28_14.stl. They are the pins you print to assemble and make things easier to link up. I used 20g Professional Liquid Super Glue from home depot or lowes to glue it together. As the name of the files imply you need 2 14x26 pins for the guard of the sword( the wingy bits). and 14 14x28 pins for the rest of it. Now remember if u are going for accurate sizing you will need to scale it all down evenly. If you are 5 foot 7 inches(170.18cm) scaling it down to .7 is a good number. Once again make it to what you want. I just don't know what you are aiming for. I have since printed another one for a smaller person. I will upload pics when I get a chance. Thanks again for the question! If there is anything else let me know. I will be looking forward to seeing yours it finished.

description.text:
My very old Ericsson T68i now has a new life as realraum's SMS Gateway. (In case of power outage, fire, somebody leaving the fridge door open, etc).
Of course we need to clip it to the wall in a nice and orderly fashion.
The clip is designed to hold the phone permanently and not to be removed.

Took a photo with CamNote of the Phone on a dark surface.
Imported the photo into Inkscape and drew the outline.
Imported the outline into FreeCad, extruded it and substracted the extrusion
from a basic clip-holder-model.

Another hot day with the lawn. Rather than stop for a drink of water, just make a holder for the bottle, so the mowing can be completed quicker!

A multitude of options in this OpenSCAD script.  Sadly, not set up for multi-part creation yet; maybe a future rev.  
Of primary note is the "bottle_diam" and "mount_diam" parameters; these control the size of the bottle and handlebar, respectively.  As coded, the mounting holes are for M3(x16) bolts.  
If your bottle has a bigger top, you may be able to print just a "top", letting gravity do the job.  Otherwise, a "bottom" will be necessary to counteract gravity...
